Sometimes you think youre getting a stout with frills, but you really dont and it ends up being a fine beer anyway. Finchs Secret Stache Stout is an example of what I mean: it claims to be a milk stout made with vanilla, but I really didnt get any. Thats okay, but the result is a solid, good-tasting, easy-drinking beer at a good price, too.

I poured a 16oz can into an English pint glass. It had an enjoy-by date of 9/23/15 and cost $2.59 ($0.16 per ounce).

Appearance: Typical black color with ruby red edges. Pours to a large, brown, frothy head which laces and retains quite well.

Smell: Noticeably vanilla sweetness at first, but quickly overshadowed by the base milk stout brew with noticeable lactose aroma and roasted malt. A bit mild, though.

Taste: Sometimes I notice when a brew is marketed as brewed with a certain specialty ingredient, that ingredient is only noticeable on the first few swigs and then blends in with the rest of the palette. Thats what happened here. The vanilla was relatively sweet, not unlike that of a candy bar. Far from cloying, for sure. It eventually fades and drinks like a familiar, traditional stout. The lactose sugar imparts some light sweetness while roasted malts offer a bit of contrast in the way of somewhat bitter/burnt flavors. Not much in the way of distinct hop flavor, though theres enough to give the palette balance. Overall, its enjoyable but I cant help but think so much more couldve been done.

Drinkability: At only 5.3% ABV, Finchs Secret Stache Stout is far from any kind of obese, imperial brew  yet too hefty to be a session beer. Theres quite a lot of body to the mouthfeel  its soft and fairly thick, but calm with a smooth texture. It leaves a slight tang in the aftertaste, but is otherwise clean. This feels like a heavier beer than it is, though. One pint was more than satisfying.

Score: 7/10

Transfer from BA review on 12-31-13-

 Served on tap in a pint glass

 Appearance  The beer is served a deep brown color with a one finger of brown head. The head fades almost instantly to leave a light level of streaky lace on the sides of the glass.

 Smell  The aroma is heaviest of a roasted malt smell mixed with a nice heavy coffee smell. Along with these aromas are some sweeter aromas of a caramel nature mixed with a little bit of a vanilla smell. A little bit of a chocolate aroma mixes with the rest producing a rather nice and sweet dark smell.

 Taste  The taste begins roasty and sweet with a good level of caramel and vanilla sweetness as well a nice roasted malt base. As the flavor advances some lighter flavors of a coffee nature come to the tongue, which start out quite light, but gains intensity as the flavor moves more toward the end. Along with this, a little bit of cocoa sweetness comes to the tongue being complimented nicely by the sweeter flavors of the beer. With a lighter flavor of char also joining the tongue at the end of the taste, one is left with a nice roasty and sweet flavor to linger on the tongue.

 Mouthfeel  The body of the beer is on the average side in its thickness and creaminess with a carbonation level that is on the lower side. The lower carbonation level is very nice for the roasted, cocoa and coffee flavors of the brew, nicely enhancing all the more intense flavors. A little thicker of a body may have been even better for the brew, but overall, at only 5.3% abv., the body was quite appropriate.

 Overall  For an only 5.3 % abv brew, this beer packs quite the flavor punch. A nice and tasty session style stout.

O: My first Finchs Beer Company beer and wont be my last. According to their website, lactose was used during the brewing process. A well done, year-round stout. I cant wait to find a 4-pack of this beer.

Very, very dark brown color. Aroma is chocolate and coffee. Taste is coffee, dark chocolate, just a hint of vanilla, some dark malt sweetness and a tad spot of bitter. Body is light for a stout. Not my favorite stout, though Im not a big-time stout fan as it is.
Can from Lazy Dog. Pours an opaque dark brown with a thin ring of toffee colored head. Aroma of roasted coffee. Taste of malts, coffee, and dark chocolates.
Tap, pours dark, light head, aroma is roasty, taste is roasty as well with a creamy and a bit sweet finish, highly drinkable and overall nice stuff

A really nice stout. Pours thick and black with massive mocha head. Aromas are vanilla and coffee with red berry notes. Flavors are sweet and creamy. Chocolate, vanilla, and coffee. Finishes robust and strong. Excellent.

Can. Pours out black with a small tan head. Aroma is vanilla, chocolate cookies (the ice cream sandwich kind) , light roast and a touch of mild coffee. Taste is complex and smooth, chocolate, medium roast coffee, vanilla bean, light finishing bitterness. Tasty with a silky smooth body

Also smores and bran muffins scents. Pours a dark brown with a large amount of thick, fluffy, tan head. Cola-like appearance in the liquid. Produces good lacing. Looks good. Quite sweet amd milky taste features flavor elements of chocolate milk, minerals, sugar, chocolate cupcake with chocolate frosting, and vanilla. Melon and peach in the finish. None of the offputting elements of the aroma make it into the flavor. Lightly dry, slightly chemical-y aftertaste. Light body. Soft and frothy in the palate. Insubstantial palate effects. Finchs Secret Stache Stout tastes very good but smells like a New York bar bathroom. It also looks good but has a subpar palate. That makes it hard to evaluate overall. It is unusual, and I do give it credit for uniqueness, at least among American sweet stouts (I suspect some old-fashioned English examples of the style share some similarities). I try to score the various elements of a beer separately, and I am perfectly willing to ding a tasty beer for smelling, in this case, literally like shit.

Can I think (didnt put it in my notes). Dark brown pour with a brown head. DArk roasted malt aromas. Sweet with vanilla and roasted malt notes. Good body and mouthfeel.

16oz can shared by JohnGonk. Pours black with a small creamy copper head. Aroma of dark chocolate, caramel, leather, roasted malt, and vanilla. Taste of burnt black malt, coffee, caramel, and vanilla.

Can.

Black with tan head. Smooth earthy front with slight vanilla coffee finish. Very good. On tap at blackfinn

Theres nice char character, very burnt flavors, sweet burnt grains, wooded earthy hops. Very bold flavors. Its quite a delicious stout. (3740)

16 ounce can from Whole Foods. Black pour with thin, tan head. Taste is upfront vanilla. But lactose as well. Not a big body since its low ABV. Pretty decent and maybe their best beer Ive had to date.

Kind of a standard milk stout with vanilla, chocolate, and roasted malt notes.   Slightly sweet, good, but nothing out of the ordinary.

Can into a goblet. Pours near black with a beautiful dark brown head. Loose lacing. Vanilla dominates the aroma with a slight bit of chocolate and coffee. Taste is creamy chocolate, coffee, and vanilla. Very full, robust flavor. Easy drinking and would expect this to be a higher ABV beer for how much flavor is here.

Draft at JoJos taphouse in Frederick, MD.  Served in a pint glass, black body with no head when I got it.  Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate milk and some vanilla.  Taste was the aroma, adding more sweetness and a slight coffee note.  Medium body, low carbonation, silky, creamy with dry finish.  Very impressed for the low ABV, great rich thick flavor.  Ill have to grab this in a can if I see it.

Can to snifter.  Black pour with a short lived beige head that turns to a light film and ring. Aroma of cacao, charred wood, and licorice. Taste is sweet cream and dark chocolate. Very creamy in the mouth.  This drinks much bigger than the ABV would suggest.  Pretty nice.
can, its like Southern Tier Creme Brulees little sister. Chocolate, vanilla, milkiness. Pretty flavorful, vanilla shines here, possibly a tad too much. Flavorful dessert beer, but a little gimicky

Can. Black pour with a short, dense mocha colored head. Aroma is big roasted malt, coffee, dark chocolate and hints of chocolate milk. Taste is chocolate milk, dark chocolate, roasted malt, coffee, light vanilla and hints of chocolate fudge. Body is medium with a dense chewy carbonation. Ends with more chocolate, chocolate milk, brownies, vanilla, roasted malt, and lighter coffee notes.

Pours a deep black with a tan head. Aroma of vanilla. Smells like a typical milk stout. Sweet taste with a smooth feel. Tasty.

22oz bomber via trade. Poured a very good looking medium density pitch black with a strong looking deep beige body. Aroma of burnt pudding, vanilla, dark toast, pudding skins, old vanilla cake. Medium to lighter bodied with softer carbonation and a quick fading after taste. Flavor is the same as the aroma, chocolate and marshmellow vanilla, ligthly burnt toast, hint of burnt citrus. Solid solid beer especially for the lower ABV.

Can shared at a local tasting, pours black with a thin brown head, the aroma has a good amount of chocolate on the nose with a little bit of coffee and vanilla, the flavor has a nice chocolate front end with a sweet finish, some coffee notes in the finish too, good mouthfeel, pretty impressed.

From a can, fairly cool, smells like strong impy stout. Look is keen.  Black and thick, viscous black used shovelhead oil. Thick and rich impact, deep while trying to be  docile. Thick dark tasting mullion of dark burned bark flavor. Not sure if the vanilla adds to much to this brew. Stout fer sure. Dark malt impact on finish. Ends with shades of old burnt dampened wood from an overnight camp fire that was put out with a warm spring rain.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: 16 ounce can into pint glass, no canning date.  Pours dense pitch black color with a 2 finger fairly dense dark tan head with good retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lingers.  Some nice spotty soapy lacing clings down the glass.  Aromas of big dark chocolate, cocoa, roasted malt, light char, coffee, toast, vanilla, toffee, cream, light floral, and roasted earthiness.  Damn nice aromas with good balance and complexity of roasted malt notes with moderate creamy vanilla; with good strength.  Taste of huge dark chocolate, roasted malt, cocoa, coffee, light char, toast, vanilla, toffee, cream, and roasted earthiness.  Slight coffee bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of dark chocolate, cocoa, roasted malt, coffee, light char, toast, vanilla, cream, and toffee on the finish for a while.  Really great balance and complexity of roasted malt flavors with moderate creamy vanilla; with huge robustness and no cloying flavors present after the finish.  Light-medium carbonation and fairly full bodied; with a very creamy and slick mouthfeel that is great.  Alcohol is very well hidden with hardly any warming noticed after the finish.  Overall this is a highly excellent vanilla cream stout!  Great flavor complexity and balance with big robustness; and very smooth to drink.  A highly enjoyable offering.

Can: Medium roast coffee, moderate strength, lesser vanilla and raisin notes. Black, thin beige head. Vanilla is the dominant note with an earthier base instead of coffee. Subtle raisin hint throughout. Quite a bit of flavor packed in a low abv stout

DRAFT at South Water Kitchen...in appropriate snifter....pours black with tan head.  Lots of chocolate nose and initial taste with strong hints of coffee.  Nice thick mouthfeel.  Very tasty...a pleasant surprise.

The color is nearly black with a small, off-white head.  The aroma has a lot of vanilla along with milk chocolate.  It has a medium, sticky body with average carbonation.  The taste is mostly sweet with a slightly roasted, dry finish.
Beer tasting. The vanilla comes through very nicely , tasty. Would definitely have more!

A good flavor but doesn't keep long once you pour it into the glass from the can. It's not something you can really drink fast either. Overall it has a good flavor of pecans, caramel, toffee, and vanilla. I like it because it is different.

Canned, deep brown with sticky legs, toasted head, aroma of milk chocolates, flavor of cocoa, vanilla, creamy body with lasting finish

Pours black with a dark kahki head. Smells of sweet milk chocolate and vanilla bean with a soft roastiness, beautiful. Same elements in the flavor but with more roast, less sweet, and more pronounced vanilla. Very very good.

Can at Wildfire Beer Dinner. Pours a syrupy aopaque blackish-brown, thin espresso colored head that dissipated quickly. Nose is roast and coffee, with some subtle chocolate and dried fruit. Big and sticky mouth, lots of rich coffee and chocolate going on here. Silky smooth and goes down really nice. Easily my favorite of the evening -- with or without the accompanying brownie! I could drink this all night.

16oz can into a pint glass.

Pours pitch plack with a thin quarter inch dark tan head that fades away within a minute to some swirling on top of the beer. A few splotches of lacing on the sides of the glass but not much else. A little bit of a let-down.

The aroma, however, more than makes up for the unimpressive aroma as it really blows me away. Tons of milk chocolate leaping out as well as coffee and a healthy dose of vanilla. There is a moderate roast tying it all together but a really mouthwatering and delicious aroma throughout.

The flavor is even better. The vanilla really stands out married nicely with milk chocolate. Almost reminds me of chocolate milk or a Hersheys bar. Coffee is there but remains in the background lending just enough roastiness to keep things from getting too sweet. Some swirls of caramel also come through with a very smooth and creamy mouthfeel finish with just a little stickyness and lingering roast.

Overall, this is possibly one of the best lower strength American Stouts I have had. The vanilla is perfectly done as it is all too often overwhelming in beers. All flavors balance perfectly and the body is awesome. Definitely a beer you should pick up if you get the chance.
UPDATED: JUN 22, 2013 Yum, yum, yum. This is one mighty-fine beer.  Beautifully dark with a smooth, rich palate.  Little to no after taste.  No bitterness at all.  Great drinkable beer.

Pours thick black like espresso with a thin tan head. Nose is umami, roasted coffee and chocolate. Tastes of roasted mildly bitter coffee, charred beef, and chocolate come through with underlying vanilla and umami notes and a touch of sweetness. Full, creamy body with low carbonation. This is a tasty, easy drinking stout with pleasant roasted bitterness thats tempered by a mild chocolate sweetness.

Can. Pours thick black with tan head. Heavy coffee aroma but thankfully not heavy on coffee grind taste. Creamy texture. Not a bad beer but I think I'm going add a touch of bourbon to it.

From can, poured a very dark brown with smaller head.  Aroma is definitely vanilla, with some roasted malt, coffee, cocoa.  Slight metallic smell.  Thick and creamy texture.  Medium bodied at least.  Slight metallic taste, maybe chaulky taste.  Light sweetness, light bitter. A solid stout that is almost great, but not there yet.

Pours pitch black with a huge "milk chocolate" head. Carbonation level is on the lower side (which I appreciate) so it (the head) doesnt stay around for too long, oh well. Aroma is really nice, with faint notes of vanilla, coffee and chocolate, I use the word "faint" but Id rather say "in their place" as none is overpowering the other, quite wonderful! Flavor is also not overpowering, unlike many beers out there there is no standout flavor here. I get a little chocolate, a little coffee and a little vanilla - in that order. It is really balanced and not a flavor bomb which often come out as roasted malts or ash bombs when speaking about stouts, a really masterful act here!

Pint can poured like motor oil, but with a durable brown head. 

Aroma: coffee, milk and dark chocolate. Less roasted malt than expected. 

T: dark roasted malts; no burnt quality; lots of dark chocolate, light vanilla and a trace of coffee, Rather sweet but not cloying. 
.
M: Full-bodied; appropriately low carbonation. Very creamy.

O: A rich and satisfying sweet stout with a wallop of chocolate malts.
Draft at Howell n hood. Black pour with white head. Vanilla bean and coffee aroma. Very heavy and tasty beer for the ABV, I like it

1 pint can. Poured a black color, with brown edges and an averaged sized tan head. Aromas of vanilla, roast, chocolate, and some coffee. Tastes of vanilla, chocolate, caramel, roast, and light coffee.

$3 16oz "tall boy" can poured into a Samuel Adams "Perfect Pint" glass.

Appearance: Pitch black... car oil kind of black. Theres a tiny head, but it goes away almost instantly, with just a thin, brown layer of foam on top. Lacing, at least initially, is sexy.

Smell: Super dark, roasted malts is the most notable thing here. However, theres plenty of chocolate-like notes as well, with some vanilla. The vanilla definitely comes out more in the aroma than it does in the flavor, which MAY be a good thing. (The vanilla is the main thing that drew me to this beer).

Taste/feel: What a stout. Forget the fact that it comes from a can. What. A. Stout. Balanced very, very well. Its never too sweet, or too bitter. Front of the sip is a bit of dark fruits (?) for sweetness, but then theres pretty much nothing but malty, chocolate goodness until the end. As the beer warms up, the beer seems to get a tad bit more bitter, and the vanilla comes out a LITTLE more, but I notice a lot of people complaining about the vanilla in it. To be honest, I dont really get much at all (at least when its cold)... and that disappoints me. Its there in a subtle way, but I actually wanted a little bit more. Regardless of that, this is still a slick-in-the-mouth, quality stout: an absolute delight.

Ar: Cocoa, oak, some sweet berries, and vanilla.
Ap: Black and opaque - medium-small mocha head with good retention and a thin, but solid, cap of lacing.
T: Chocolate and raisins, medium sweetness, up front - smooth vanilla, coffee, and char - vanilla and milk chocolate, with a fair bit of ash on the finish.
P: Medium-full body and creamy-smooth - carbonation is medium.
O: Full and luscious stout - nice balance of flavors,- a very well-done vanilla accent, which avoids the medicinal quality that sometimes comes across in vanilla beers - delicious, and ideal for dessert.
From a can, aroma is roasted malt, light vanilla. Taste is smooth roast malt and chocolate. Very nice for St Pattys!

UPDATED: MAR 31, 2013 After drinking several more of these beers, Ive lowered my rating. Much too sweet, and the vanilla nukes most other flavors! Beautiful appearance, and solid body, dont off set the sweet/vanilla!
black in color with brown head fading away quickly. aroma is roasty malt and vanilla. medium bodied beer with good bitterness and prominent vanilla flavor.  a good stout would try again.

tap - Pours near black with a small tan head. It smells of dark roast malt and maybe some vanilla though I dont know if Id have noticed without knowing the name of the beer first. It tastes of coffee accented dark roast malt with chocolate and vanilla notes. Its a very tasty medium bodied brew.
Draught. Pours a thick and near-black color with almost no head. Nose is quite chocolaty, actually, with some nice roasting underneath. Taste is much the same, and feels very smooth. Good brew.

16 oz can 5.3 alc Opaque ebony with a lasting disc of creamy foam. Big nose of dark chocolate, oatmeal, espresso, burnt caramel, toasted nut, berry.  Taste is the same great mix with maybe a bit more lactose and berry, plus some vanilla coffee.  Medium body is sweet, but not sticky, and very smooth with low-medium carbonation.

Tap at Milltown.  Opaque black with no head, minuscule lace.  Nose is strong vanilla, cocoa, light coffee, and sweeter roast.  Flavor shows vanilla more prominently--also a sweet hazelnut like nuttiness/cocoa thing--a lot like
Nutella, with some honey and sweet nougat.  More vanilla.  Oily, slick medium bodied with a slight cherry cough syrup bite.  Okay, but didnt realize this was a vanilla stout until after I ordered it.  Have yet to find a vanilla themed beer that I like.  Well made, but way too sweet for me.

Brewhaha. One of the better beers tasted at the event. Dark brown, firm lasting brown head. Interesting stout. Roasted malts, chocolate, a hint of coffee, some alcohol. Good body and full soft carbo. Overall a good brew.

Tall boy from Sams, Durham. Nice to see these folks pop up unexpectedly in NC. Having enjoyed a couple of their paler, hoppier brews, it was nice to take a crack at this one. Slightly thinner pour than optimal, I guess, but silky and firm enough. Nose of soft chocolate and vanilla extract, making me wonder about the integrity of the base beer. Slightly thinner and sweeter overall than is my preference but a solid entry nonetheless.

Pours an oily black with a medium tan head.  Aroma is dominated by a strong vanilla aroma.  This goes along with chocolate and hints of coffee.  The taste has more balance between the vanilla and chocolate, with the vanilla still being on top.  After the initial taste, more flavors come out.  Coffee, caramel, and butterscotch.  Aftertaste contains more coffee and less chocolate.  This one is light in body with a smooth, creamy texture.  This is different than others in this style.  If you like vanilla, youd probably enjoy it.

Can. Ink black pour, tan head, little retention/good lace. Aroma of vanilla, chocolate, roast, espresso. Taste is lightly sweet, dark chocolate, vanilla, light peat, roast. Palate is soft, creamy, rich finish. Really nice.

Pint can from Binnys Lincoln Park. Pours a black body with a finger-width, creamy, dark brown head that dissipates slowly and leaves a nice lacing. Aroma is vanilla, bittersweet milky chocolates, roasts and earth, cream, and caramel. Flavor is similar. Vanilla and bittersweet cocoas up front before some drier earth comes in. Stays pretty creamy throughout despite the slight dry feel. Some toasts and more roasts come out towards the end as this finishes somewhat bitter, but smooth and sweet with a good amount of vanilla. Lengthy aftertaste following a creamy, medium body and a soft, light carbonation. Overall, a really solid and flavorful stout. Rich and sweet, but somewhat dry and well balanced with all the vanilla. Good beer.

Pours bitch black with a large brown head. Smells roasted, chocolaty, and of vanilla. Taste is chocolate and vanilla with some roast tones underneath. Medium-to-full bodied with a smooth texture and soft mouth-carbonation, Finchs Secret Stache Stout finishes with a blended sweetness of chocolate and vanilla.

Pours black with a thin mocha head.  Aroma has wonderful dark chocolate notes.  Flavor has lots of dark chocolate and just a touch of burnt bitterness and a hint of peat/smoke cutting through the sweetness.  Mouthfeel is full and creamy with a nice dark chocolate finish.

Can.  Pours black with a very thin tan head.  Aroma of vanilla, roasted malt, bitter chocolate.  Flavor of sweet vanilla, lactose, chocolate, and roast in the finish.  Great vanilla stout - very hearty and rich for a low abv beer!
8/48/4/14 [3.8/5]

Black pour with a chunky brown head that laces all the way down. Massive roasted malt, chocolate, coffee and vanilla beans. Fantastic flavor of chewy chocolate, roast, coffee beans and vanilla. Great creamy mouthfeel with a bittersweet ending. Damn good beer.

Pours a deep brown with thick tan head, decent lacing.  Aroma of vanilla, roasted chocolate malt, caramel, and very slight coffee.  Flavor matches well and comes together quite nicely, especially after being quite skeptical when opening it.

Can sample at a tasting at Yoavs place. Thanks Dror Sparrow. Pours black, opaque with brown ring, coffee, slightly wooden vanilla aroma, sweet, medicinal, hot chocolate and faint vanilla taste. Smooth, hardly any carbonation, medium body, long finish and a little oily texture. Good, complex and surprising.

Can sample at a tasting at Yoavs place. Thanks Dror Sparrow. Black with a light brown foam. Sweet aroma of dark chocolate, vanilla, a bit of milk and a bit of coffee. Nice flavor of chocolate and vanilla, sweetish with a moderately bitter finish. Medium-bodied. Good.

Pours a nice dark brown color with a quickly fading light brown head. Aroma is simple with vanilla, roast and Oreo cookies. Flavor is smooth and quite rich for 5.3%. Lots of vanilla, roast and chocolate.

16oz can, shared by Jay. Black color. Thin brown head, fades a bit, but leaves decent lace. Vanilla, cocoa powder in the nose. Light body. Kind of a chewy texture. Light carbonation. A bit thin, but it does go down easy. Sweet taste, vanilla, chocolate milk in the flavor. Nice one, if youre looking for a light, drinkable vanilla flavored sweet stout
Man this stuff is good. A real nice rich dessert, but not too big, so it?s soooo easy to drink. Tons of body and flavor for a 5.3% ABV Stout. Nailed it!

Pours pitch black, aromas of espresso, bakers chocolate. The taste is full of roasted notes with a bitter coffee finish. This beer amazes me, the mouth feel is very full for the low abv, I almost dont believe this is 5.3% awesome stuff all around.

16 oz can.  Dark brown with tan froth.  Nose is vanilla, mocha, more vanilla and caramel; maybe some toasted coconut, yummy.  Creamy mouthfeel finishing with a sharp, roasty tang.  Taste is light molasses, coffee, bittersweet chocolate and vanilla.  I thought this would be too sweet but ended up nicely balanced.  A great gateway brew for the uninitiated.

Draft sample at IBGWF 2013. Poured clear dark ruby color with an average to large frothy brown head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Moderate to heavy sweet chocolate malt and vanilla aroma. Medium to full body with a smooth texture and flat carbonation. Medium to heavy toasted malt and sweet vanilla ice cream flavor with a medium to heavy sweet finish of moderate to long duration. This is a solid smooth brew.

Theres something about this thats awesome.  Its dark brown with a slightly glowy brown head.  There are signs of dangerousness.  Like a spider.  It has a smooth, soft, vanilla aroma.  Its distinctively different.  The flavor is deserty, like vanilla icing.  Otherwise, its just your stereotypical stout.  Although its low in alcohol, it feels much like how alcohol thins the body of a beer, making for a slick mouth feel thats rich and reminiscent of a porter. This is one viscous beer.

Can, supplied by StFunwicked cool, thanks! Been just dying to try. Cant believe I hadnt when I visited Chicago. Okay, to snifter it pours an inky, purplish-black with a crème brûlée tinted head, not even  a pinky-nail in length. Has aromas of vanilla beans (intense), molasses, roast, refined sugar, oat flour, and raspberry syrup. Lovely! Tastes sweet, but not too sweet, with undercurrents of vanilla, cream soda, sorghum molasses, sugar cane, hops, tree bark and oats. Ends bittersweet and slightly earthy with notes of stale gingerbread, minerals, red cabbage, and more vanilla. What a beer indeed.

Can.  Pours an opaque dark brown with a thing whispy tan head.  Aroma is dark roast coffee with a sweet chocolatey note.  Nice creamy feel with a pleasant carbonation.  Finishes slightly bitter and dry.  Semi-sweet roast body.

Opaque black pour with two fingers of dark brown, frothy head. Very pretty. Lots of spotty lace. Aroma was full of dark cocoa, vanilla, roasted malt. Kinda like a melted candy bar. Flavors were much of the same. Tons of rich chocolate flavors, vanilla, sweet cream, lightly roasted malt, more cocoa. Rich velvety mouthfeel, lighter carbonation. This ran like a really good milk stout with gobs of vanilla and chocolate thrown in. Very good.

16oz Can, pretty fresh.  Served at around 55F.

Pours black with a two finger rich brown head, leaves beautiful drippy rings and sheets of lacing and holds a good cap.  Purty.

Aroma is vanilla, chocolate, roasted malts, vanilla, chocolate, roasted malts...thats pretty much it, but thats all there needs to be.  Good to very good strength.

Flavor is more of the same, vanilla, rich creamy chocolate, roasted malts, coffee, fairly sweet, minimal bitterness, minimal alcohol.  Very tasty.

Mouthfeel is medium bodied, very creamy, gotta figure theres some oatmeal at work here, soft to moderate carbonation.  Smooth and easy drinking.

Man this stuff is good.  A real nice rich dessert, but not too big, so its soooo easy to drink.  Tons of body and flavor for a 5.3% ABV Stout.  Nailed it!
On tap at Kellehers, Peoria. Dark pour with a tan head. Aroma was roasted malt, maybe black patent also. Sweetness. Taste is roasted malt, sweetness of vanilla, very tasty.

16 ounce can, as shown in the photo. Pitch black and syrupy in appearance.  It leaves a swampmonster goo on the glass when you swirl it around. Vanilla and coffee bean aromas pair together nicely. Taste wise, this is one of the first beers where Ive enjoyed a plainly present vanilla aspect.  Thick in body and smooth in mouthfeel- low carbonation. Its all delicious and probably as healthy as a double bacon cheeseburger.

Pounder can from Capones.  Pours..wow, this one pours motor oily thick black with dark brown edges and minimal tan head.  Nose is black patent malt, choc malt, cacao, and mild vanilla.  Tastes rich, with a big black patent and chocolate malt flavor, cacao, ovaltine, hazelbut, and mild anise.  Complex in the flavor and pretty hefty in the mouthfeel, this one is really good.

Comes out of the can a rich, deep, coffe-like sable with a very thick and rather persistent tan head. Aroma has notes of roast malt, chocolate and good coffee, plus an undertone of vanilla. Robust flavor has smoky, vanilla, mocha and toffee notes, some sweetness but not too much. Texture is smooth, firm and somewhat fizzy. Glad this "secret" is out!

Deep dark pour with a ring of tan head. Vanilla and milky roast with some coffee and espresso notes. Taste is similar, with bitter roast mixing with the coffee and vanilla. Medium-thin with some minimal carbonation.

UPDATED: JAN 21, 2013 Can This beer rocks! Pitch black pour with a small, creamy, taupe head. The aroma supplies gobs of dark chocolate, milk chocolate and caramel. Im not picking up much vanilla  its there, but I really had to dig for it. Full-bodied and über creamy  fatty even  with feather-soft carbonation. At room temperature, both the flavor and finish are malty, carbonic swirls of bittersweet dark chocolate and espresso with only a sliver of vanilla. The best moderate-gravity stout Ive tried in a very long while! A session stout that drinks like an imperial stout. Huge thanks to StFun for including this can as an extra in a trade!

Pretty great opaque looking 5.3% beer if you ask me, looks creamy with a dark tan cap.
The nose is milk chocolate with a bit of roasty notes sort of like a mild coffee, little sweetness.
The vanilla comes out much more in the flavors then the aroma, makes a vanilla creamy coffee sort of deal, but the sweetness is strong and lasting.
mouthfeel is low carb and creamy in an almost nitro way, great.

This is the best beer Finch has made yet, or maybe i should say the only noteworthy beer theyve made yet, i really dig it. one of the better 5% stouts ive had at all.

Love,
Chad

Serving type: can
Aroma is fruit, slight sweetness and a hint of roasted malts.  The flavor is coffee, vanilla, chocolate, roasted malts and a mix of earthiness and mild tartness in the finish.

can.  jet black with a large, fluffy, dark brown head.  milk chocolate aroma.  flavor has that kind of  bitter vanilla extract flavor beneath a heavily roasted and chocolaty malt base with moderate sweetness.  a milky and smooth palate that im really diggin.  like theres a dollop of sugar free vanilla ice cream in it.  an easy drinking, highly sessionable stout.

Draft. Pours black like used oil with a half finger of dark tan head. Aroma is huge vanilla. Coffee, chocolate and black licorice follow. Taste is about the same. Medium sweet. Vanilla, caramel, licorice with a hint of oak. Full bodied with a thick and creamy texture. Soft carbonation and a very very long finish. Overall, great. Ive not been too impressed with most of the stuff from Finch, but this one kicks ass.
16 oz can pours black with a tan head.  Aroma of toffee, malt, coffee and chocolate.  Taste is the roasted malt, coffee and vanilla at the finish.

Growler. Pours black with a small brown head that quickly dissipated.  Aroma is roast, vanilla, dark chocolate and espresso.  Taste is a perfect bittersweet.  Medium bodied with a creamy texture.  Really enjoyed this.

Draft at Jerrys.  Black with foamy brown head, light lacing / Grassy, toasty nose of roast barley, coffee, and chocolate / Medium body, a touch thin, acidic with some sweetness and chew, with otherwise good balance and bitter finish / Flavors of grass, dark roast coffee, cocoa, vanilla, and cooked dark fruit / A little flabby of body and flavor, and youve got to really love vanilla.
Best Craft Dry Irish Stout in my opinion! Rich Chocolate Hue, milk like texture with hints of chocolate and vanilla.

Really dark brew with a lot going on. Dense on the nose with hints of vanilla, roasted malt, and tan foam on top tat disappears. Well hidden alcohol, and a super pillowy, smooth texture. A really delicious, exceptional stout.
Can. Pours black with minimum head. The aroma Is vanilla up front. The taste is vanilla extract and bean.. Big sweetness.

a 5% stout? In a can? Hmmm.. Served fairly cold in a pint glass. No head was produced. Poured midnight black. I can smell vanilla from a few feet away. licorice and tobacco on the nose. Taste is very pleasant. Sweet, vanilla, toffee, oak and licorice. Medium body despite the midnight oily color. Decent beer.

On tap at Ervs Mug.  Dark brown with a creamy tan head.  Aroma of coffee, roasted malt, chocolate, caramel and espresso.  Taste of dark chocolate, brown sugar, mild vanilla, dark malts and a hint of dark fruit.  Mild bitter finish, nice stout.

Bottle.  Deep, thick black pour with yellow-tan head.  Light roast, dark fruit, brown sugar, background vanilla, and some mild oxidation/cardboard.  Flavor is a heavy, fairly acidic roast with some dark fruit.  Barely perceivable vanilla in the background.   Moderate to heavy lingering coffee, roast grain, and soapy hops.  Nice, medium palate.  Enough vanilla to add mild complexity, but not enough to really take notice.  Flavor certainly tops the nose on this one.

Can:  The aroma consists of chocolate syrup, vanilla, and light roasted coffee.  It pours a dark brown with no transparency and a small tan head that quickly fades to a thin ring around the edges of the glass.  The flavor starts with sweet milk chocolate.  Theres some light-moderate sweet vanilla notes in the middle.  The finish has some light roasted coffee.  Its medium bodied with soft carbonation and mouthfeel.  Overall, it may be a simple, but its pretty tasty and not overloaded with vanilla.

Pretty much exactly what I want from a Stout! Love the art work, and that it comes in a Can! 

Rich chocolate, coffee, vanilla on the nose. Pours oily black with rich caramel colored head that dies quickly but leaves thick brown sticky lacing. Tastes exactly how it smells. I worry when I hear brewed with vanilla that I will get a syrupy sweetness but not here, just a hint of vanilla. Dry coffee and dark chocolate notes, splash of lactose and under carbonated (which is perfect for this beer)

All I want to give this a perfect score is bourbon aging, please please please put this on bourbon!

16 oz. can. Opaque ebony with a lasting disc of creamy foam. Big nose of dark chocolate, oatmeal, espresso, caramel, toasted nut, berry,  and char. Taste is the same great mix with maybe a bit more lactose and berry, plus some iodine and driftwood. Medium body is sweet, but not sticky, and very smooth with low-medium carbonation.

Black, with a sturdy brown head. Smells like marshmallow, with some chocolate notes. Taste is like on of those chocolate covered marshmallow cookies - Mallomars? The greatest cookie ever invented? Yeah...

On tap at Honeypie. First pour of a new keg, I am told. Pours very dark brown with a brownish head. A bit of a foam up leaving nice lacing. Aroma has chococaramel, some expresso and a hint of raspberry. Taste is of roasted malts, some chocolate, some brown sugar and some soy. More and more roasted malt/coffee through the glass. Finishes roasty bitter with a nice sweetness. The best of the finches Ive had, certainly.

Draft in pint glass. 
Light head. Rich aroma - chocolate coffee vanilla. 
Light roasted chocolate coffee flavor is quite nice, less powerful than the aroma would lead you to believe but smooth.

This brew is a dark brownish-black color with a medium tan head that diminishes steadily. Small patches of lacing. Aroma of sweet malt, chocolate and vanilla. Light-bodied with a roasty malt and vanilla character with some cocoa in the background. The finish is sweet with a short chocolate/vanilla aftertaste. Decent overall.

Bottle shared by Dogbrick at Septoberfest V: Septoberfest Rises on 9/29/12. Black pour with a medium tan head. Malty nose with notes of licorice and chocolate. Chocolate malt flavor with slight metal before a roasty finish.
Bottle thanks to Matt. Pours black with brown head. Nose/taste of vanilla, coffee roast, black licorice, roasted chocolate malt and vanilla bean. Medium body. Nice dry roasted finish.

A very nice and surprising Vanilla Stout! Received in a recent trade, thanks so much! I The vanilla is well integrated with the stout, sweet, but not over the top.  Flavor is roast, vanilla, dark chocolate, and slight coffee. A very easy drinking and delicious beer!

Thanks to GhostFace for this one in the local beer swap.  Cheers, Neal!  Pours a deep obsidian color with a dark tan head.  Nose is roasted malts, earth, coffee, slight licorice, and mild vanilla.  Flavor is roast, vanilla, dark chocolate, coffee, earth, licorice, and some mild hoppy bitterness and vanilla notes on the back end.  A sessionable, complex, roasty and vanilla stout?  Outstanding!

Pours black with a very dark tan head.
Scent is licorice, vanilla, roast coffee.
Taste is cream, chocolate....a slight ashy bitter.
A nice straightforward stout....maybe a wee bit on the thin side, but Very tasty.

(22oz bottle) clearish espresso, sparse tan bubbles. Nose of vanilla, fudge, Marshmallow, rich and slight metal tinge. Taste of malt balls, cream, fairly burnt malt, but metallic. Medium thick body that somehow lacks overall.

Bomber bottle from Binnys and served in Duvel snifter: Pours a deep brown near opaque with an initial frothy deep tan head which does fade leaving good rings of lace. The aroma has notes of roast and toast, some coffee, chocolate, vanilla and leather, light prune, liquorice and fig, with a dash of grassy hops. The taste is rather straight forward sweet and roasted malts along with chocolate and light vanilla. Some dark fruit and lactic twang with a cardboardy and ashy finish. The mouth feel is smooth and ashy. It is okay, the vanilla is quite restrained which for me is a good thing. Honestly something I will likely not buy again.
Deep dark, Brown head. Aroma is really faint, egg, cream. Flavor is light chocolate, roaster marshmallows. Creamy and roasty, but still pretty light.

22 ounce bottle.  Served in a nonic pint glass, the beer pours dark brown/black with about a half inch brown head that stays around for a while.  Theres a good amount of lacing left on the glass.  Aroma is a bit light, but still nice.  The brew smells like bittersweet and milk chocolate, vanilla, roasted malt, and a little bit of coffee.  The taste is just like the aroma, but I think its stronger in comparison to the aroma.  Also, I think this is more of a sweeter stout as the milk chocolate and vanilla flavors are stronger than the other ones are.  Mouthfeel/body is medium, its a bit slick and creamy with good carbonation.  I think its a good overall brew, its definitely worth a try at $5.99 a bomber.
Pours ink black with two fingers of creamy coffee brown head.  Nose shows rich chocolate and espresso roast, light acidity and notes of black cherry skins and licorice.

22oz bottle. picked this one up because the price was right, but i am pleasantly surprised! pours out  a dark brown, appearance is almost black, on the thicker side. thin head atop the liquid. aroma is sweet and of dark chocolate, some vanilla and a bit of lightly roasted coffee bean. none of which are over powering. creamy feel on the tongue. vanilla and coffee flavors stand out with a bit of a roasted flavor and a tad bitter. good stuff!
Bottle.  Chocolate, coffee malt aroma.  Black color with small head.  Chocolate malt, ash, and herbal hops flavor.  Very nice beer.
Bottle shared in line at DLD. Chocolate, coffee, ash, prune aroma. Black with a small creamy tan head. Coffee, sweet chocolate, ash, peat, and slight acidic flavor. Smooth full body.

Bomber.  Poured fairly thick, deep black with a creamy dark brown head.. looked great!  The aroma picked up roasty chocolate and other black malts with accents of vanilla and slightly-sweetened licorice.. nice, but just a hair sweet for me.  The flavor found burnt licorice and sweeter, milky chocolates at the core.. grainy cocoa and sweet vanilla on the edges.. finished sweet with residual cocoa and licorice sugars plus a welcome hit of lactic sourness.. tasty stuff.  Medium-plus bodied and quite dense on the palate.. good feel and flow, but too thick and a little cloying at times.. overall really, really good stuff!

22oz bottle 4/11/12 (Binnys Downers Grove)-40° in English Pint-Pours pitch black with a one finger brown head. Aroma of chocolate and more chocolate. Taste of chocolate, malt, and coffee. This medium to full bodied brew is well balanced and quite tasty. Nice job.
Surprising entry from Finchs -- hope to see it again in the future, its a keeper!

Draft at Stout Fest. Glad to see Finchs doing something interesting. Pours a deep black-brown with a tan head. The nose is cocoa forward, some soft vanilla sweetness and roast. On tasting, much the same. Nice level of cocoa, medium-full bodied, creamy. The vanilla is not overpowering, which is nice. One of my favorites from Finchs...

A: This stout pours a real nice oily black. In fact there is no light visible through the beer even being held up to a light. A beautiful mocha one finger head forms that recedes quickly. The lacing on this thing is ridiculously awesome. As the head does recede it just clings to my glass and as I tip and swirl it just grabs on and slowly glides back down.

S: Upon first smell I definitely pick up the vanilla (it is an ale brewed with vanilla). In fact it smells like a vanilla marshmallow. I also pick up some bitter chocolate, roasted malts and ever so slight coffee.

T: In the taste I do get the vanilla although not as I was expecting. It is sweet at first taste but then the bitter chocolate takes over. I pick up some wood/smokey notes on the finish.

M: The mouthfeel is rather light and not as chewey as I thought it might be. I get a mild prickliness from the carbonation although it is very moderate. As I allow it to coat my mouth it does seem to linger after swallowing and the creamy feel is intriging. The more I sip and review I am enjoying the mouthfeel on this one. Not too viscous and not too watery. 

O: At $5.99 this one is hard to beat! Great job Finchs on a really enjoyable easy drinking stout. I hope they offer this one again because I would buy more for sure.

Bottle. Pours black with a dark brown head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma has a good amount of roast with a bit of dark chocolate and a hint of coffee. Flavor starts with a good amount of roasted malts with a bit of coffee and bitter chocolate in the finish.
This is a pleasant stout with a good balance of roasty bitterness and smooth vanilla.
Good solid beer by Finchs caramel, chocolate, coffee, vanilla, black, brown foam, medium sweetness, full body,
Bottle.  Pours black with a tan head.  Aroma of roasted malt and chocolate.  Solid flavor.  Good beer for the price.  Sweet.

22 ounce bottle

A cheap bottle was my first pickup after relocating and checking out some of the local stores. Based on this I hope a couple more of their beers make it down south. A solid beer is worth checking it if you happen to have access to it.

Aroma / Appearance - The oily black pour was deep, dense, and darker than I thought possible for a mere 5% ABV release. The mocha tinted head is just as dark. Coffee, vanilla, and a rich chocolate feel give this the texture of a velvet cupcake next to a cup of Starbucks espresso.

Flavor / Palate - Chewiness provides a nice ebb and flow. With smokiness, chocolate, and a bitter undertone the beer entices you to keep going back for more until the bottle is empty. This is a solid release regardless of the fact that it is a mere $4.99. Chicago has yet another promising up and coming brewery to add to the list of options.

Poured from a 22 oz. bottle into a 14.75 oz. stout/porter glass.

Ar: Vanilla and roasted malt fills the nostrils with chocolate and toffee undertones.

Ap: Pours almost pitch black with a dark tan half finger head that dissipates quickly into a thin foam ring that borders the inside of the glass. 

T: Vanilla and burnt caramel dominate, transitions into roasted malt that turns back to vanilla and finishes smooth with a touch of sweetness.

P: Near perfect carbonation for the style. Medium body that at times shows a bit more muscle. Slick yet satifying.

O: This is truly a solid offering from Finch, and their best beer to date. Very drinkable, yet has enough body to leave no doubt that this is a stout. Very reasonable $5.99 price point.

Bomber. Black body with no head. A few fizzy bubbles. Chocolate aroma with notes of vanilla, cocoa, ash. charred wood. The flavor is moderately sweet and lightly bitter. It finishes lightly to moderately sweet and lightly to moderately bitter. Medium body, watery texture and moderate carbonation. Dry ashiness dominates the taste with notes of chocolate and a hint of vanilla. Average stout, lacking the richness and complexity of better stouts.

22 oz bottle from Binnys South Loop (Chicago, IL). Opted to by a bottle over having it at a fest. Pours a rich blackish hue, inky opaque body is dark and intimidating, a frother darker brown head sits atop, froths at a decent layer, laces well and sticks around. Surprisingly dark and firm. Aromas throw a healthy deal of vanilla, creamy sweetness yet mellow, with touches of cocoa, soda bread, dryness, and toffee. Biscuits and milk chocolate, coffee and cream. Vanilla beans, touches of dry earth and ashy qualities. Initial is medium bodied, perhaps a bit more (surprising forr its ABV girth) than expected, with a good deal of vanilla, cocoa, and dryness. Touches of ash, soda bread, biscuits. Into the middle roasty and earthy, ashy and dry, covering up some cocoa, coffee, and lingering vanilla. Overall, pretty well put together, the vanilla is firm but not overdone as the backend provides some healthy dryness to combat any sweetness that may have started to get out of hand. If anything, Im surprised it doesnt get as such. Pretty nice, lingering coffee, biscuits, and vanilla into the finish. Pretzels stick with me into the afterglow. Pretty nice beer by Finch here.

Pours a black, very thick and a low, dense, deep dark tan head that sits atop it. Aroma has a lot of burn malt notes, light coffee with a finishing dark chocolate sweetness. Flavor has a pronounced hefty acrid roasted kick but this is quickly countered by a strong dark chocolate sweetness. Some coffee notes are in there but come off more like a good hot chocolate due to the bitter/sweetness combo described earlier. Beer is oily, thick and contains almost zero carbonation. Overall a very tasty brew but I dont get any vanilla. Vanilla is normally one of those ingredients that you smell right off the bat, not the case here. A tasty brew as a whole and I love the density of it as this is becoming harder to find.

This is extremely dark for a beer of this gravity, opaque black with a deep brown head. Even so, it is not harsh or overbearing. Dark chocolate is the main aromatic componenet with abit of coffee. The vanilla is subdued and lens a smooth fruity quality. My only complaints are a bit of ash flavor and a slight alcoholic heat. Still, those are minor at the worst. The creamy texture and full flavor at a relatively low gravity make this a very satisfying brew.
what i cant figure out is what kind of reaction the other bird on the label is having to the bird with the stache. which doesnt look very secret.

22oz pours opaque dark brown almost black. now first glass had a decent dark brown head that didnt last very long and the 2nd glass didnt have much of a head at all. lacing is a bit oily and slides down the glass. the aroma of chocolate and vanilla and some roasted malts. the flavor is about the same and meshes together rather nicely. the roasted malt is upfront and a bit bitter followed with the chocolate/vanilla flavors. not a bad stout but its not the best either...glad i got to try it.

No matter how I poured this, I could not get it to form a head, except for a few dark tan bubbles across the top.  Aroma is simpler than I had hoped for: mostly vanilla with some chocolate and roasted coffee flavors.  Body is as full as expected, with a texture between oily and milky.  Hardly any carbonation. Taste is sweet with a little hoppy bitterness in the finish.  Very drinkable but overall not as good as I expected from Finchs.

Not much going on aroma wise.  Some general roast character and a hint of vanilla.  A very violent pour produced almost no head.  What there was was the color of medium toast.  "soap bubbles" linger on the sides.  The taste is of espresso and vanilla.  A bit of oak (probably from the vanilla, not actual oak).  Medium-thick body and a lot of residual sweetness.  The low carbonation is perfect for the style.  This would do well on nitro.  Overall, a mixed bag.  I wish there were more aroma and a touch less sweetness, but the flavor and carbonation are spot on.  This is the best Ive seen from Finchs thus far.

All around great brew. Smell is roasty malt and you catch a little sweet smell from the vanilla and it being a milk stout. Great roastyness to it. Goes down very smooth at 5.3. Really enjoyed this offering.
